The year '''2008 in [[art]]''' involves various significant events.
==Events== *A [[Fernand Léger]] painting ''Woman and Child'' (1921), which was at first on loan for an exhibit from the Davis Museum at [[Wellesley College]] in [[Wellesley, Massachusetts]] to the [[Oklahoma City Museum of Art]] while the Davis was closed for renovations, is later returned and then stored in a crate at Wellesley, but disappears in the intervening period; the work has not been seen since.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2008/09/11/first_they_lose_a_leger/|title=First They Lose a Leger|first=Richard|last=Lacayo|authorlink=Richard Lacayo|date=2008-09-11|accessdate=2017-12-05|work=[[time (magazine)|Time]]}}</ref> *May – Police seize photographs by [[Bill Henson]] from an upcoming exhibition at the [[Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]], as potentially constituting [[child pornography]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/henson-fight-will-rage-on/story-e6frg8n6-1111116564757|title=Bill Henson fight will rage on despite the law|last1=Perkin|first1=Corrie|first2=Michael|last2=Pelly|date=2008-06-07|work=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=2012-08-28}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== * [[20 February]] until [[18 May]] – [[National Gallery]], ''[[Pompeo Batoni]]''<ref>[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/whats-on/past/pompeo-batoni National Gallery website]. Accessed 25 February 2014</ref> *[[July 4]] until [[September 14]] - "[[Robert Indiana]] a [[Milano]]" at the Padiglione d’Arte Contemporanea (Pavilion of Contemporary Art) in Milan, [[Italy]]<ref>http://www.artsblog.it/post/2022/tra-pop-e-tipografia-robert-indiana-a-milano</ref>
==Works== {{see also|Category:2008 sculptures}} *''[[Cairns (sculpture)|Cairns]]'', installation in Portland, Oregon, by Christine Bourdette *[[La Danse de la fontaine émergente]], fountain in Paris designed by [[Chen Zhen (artist)|Chen Zhen]] and completed by his widow Xu Min *''[[Of All The People In All The World]]'', installation and performance<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/sep/13/centrallistings.theatre2|title=Guardian: Theatre preview|accessdate=2008-09-24|work=[[The Guardian]]|last=Gardner|first=Lyn|date=2008-09-13|location=London}}</ref> by [[Stan's Cafe]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox court case | name = ''Amar Nath Sehgal v. Union of India'' | court = [[Delhi High Court]] | imagesize = | date decided = 21 February 2005 | full name = | judges = Justice [[P Nandrajog]] | opinions = | citations = 2005 (30) PTC 253 (Del) | keywords = [[Moral rights (copyright law)|moral rights in copyright]] }}
'''''Amar Nath Sehgal v. Union of India'''''<ref name=judgment>{{cite web|title=Amar Nath Sehgal v. Union of India|url=http://www.indiankanoon.org/doc/1990275/|publisher=Indian Kannon|accessdate=28 February 2012}}</ref> is a landmark Indian case decided by the [[Delhi High Court]], which for the first time upheld the [[moral rights (copyright law)|moral right]] of an author under the [[Copyright law of India|Indian Copyright Act]] and awarded damages. The government was also asked to return his mural.<ref>{{cite web|title=India Key milestones for intellectual property|url=http://www.buildingipvalue.com/07AP/p.266-269%20India.pdf|publisher=BuildingIPValue.com|accessdate=28 February 2012|author=Pravin Anand|author2=Keshav S Dhakad|format=PDF}}</ref><ref name="RadhakrishnanBalasubramanian2008">{{cite book|author1=Radhakrishnan|author2=Dr. R Radhakrishnan and Dr.S. Balasubramanian|title=Intellectual Property Rights: Text and Cases|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nEc8PtMOuzsC&pg=PA62|accessdate=20 August 2013|year=2008|publisher=Excel Books India|isbn=978-81-7446-609-9|pages=62–}}</ref>
==Facts== The plaintiff, [[Amar Nath Sehgal]] is a renowned artist and sculptor, who created a mural in the lobby of [[Vigyan Bhawan]], Delhi on the direction of appropriate authority. In the year 1957, the Government of India commissioned Mr. Sehgal for creating a bronze mural for Vigyan Bhavan, the most prominent International Convention Hall in Delhi. The Bronze sculpture so commissioned, of about 140 ft. span and 40 ft. sweep took five years to complete and was placed on the wall of the Lobby in the Convention hall. This embellishment on a national architecture became a part of the Indian art heritage. However, in 1979, the mural was pulled down and consigned to the store room of the Union without notice or permission or authorization of Amarnath. When Mr. Sehgal came to know of this ill treatment, he made representations to the government authorities for restoration of the mural, to no avail. As this act of destruction of the mural as it was improperly handled which cause minor damage to the sculpture. He filed a petition under Section 57 of the Copyright Act, 1957 in the Delhi High Court praying for an apology from the defendants, a permanent injunction on the defendants to restrain them from distorting, mutilating or damaging the plaintiff’s mural and damages to the tune of Rs. 50 lacs.
==Judgment== The Court termed the Moral rights as the soul of the author’s works. "The author has a right to preserve, protect and nurture his creations through his moral rights. A creative individual is uniquely invested with the power and mystique of original genius, creating a privileged relationship between a creative author and his work."
The Court elucidated on the moral rights that flow from art and literary work .They are Identification right or attribution right, right to dissemination, Right to integrity that is to maintain the purity of work and right to withdraw from the publication of the work .The language of the Section 57 makes it possible to legally protect the cultural heritage of India through the moral rights of the artist. "Intellectual property and knowledge are interconnected. Intellectual property embodies traditional thought and knowledge with value addition. Thus, physical destruction or loss of intellectual property has far reaching social consequence. Knowledge which has grown with it is also lost." Court ruled that moral rights in the work of art acquire the status of the cultural heritage of the nation and India being a signatory to many conventions , it would be the obligation of the state to protect such work.
Further, Section 57 of the Copyright Act, 1957 includes destruction of a work of art as a ground as it is the extreme form of mutilation and reduces the volume of the author’s creative corpus and affects his reputation prejudicially as being actionable under said section. Further, in relation to the work of an author, subject to the work attaining the status of a modern national treasure, the right would include an action to protect the integrity of the work in relation to the cultural heritage of the nation.
The Court held that the plaintiff has a cause to maintain an action under Section 57 of the Copyright Act, 1957 even though the copyright in the mural stands vested in the defendants. It was further held that the defendants have not only violated the plaintiff's moral right of integrity in the mural but have also violated the integrity of the work in relation to the cultural heritage of the nation. The Court ordered the defendants to return to the plaintiff the remnants of the mural permanently with no rights vesting with the defendants henceforth and ordered the defendants to pay damages with costs.
==Significance of the Decision== The decision taken by the single bench of the Delhi High Court was instrumental in determining the course of moral rights in the country. It also gave a broad construction to the term moral rights in the country, by not only providing for the right of the author in the case of any distortion, mutilation, modification or other act in relation to the work if such distortion etc. would be prejudicial to his honour or reputation but also ‘right of the author to receive the copyrighted work for the purposes of restoration and sell it’. It included within the moral right of integrity the right to protect an artistic work from outright destruction. The interim decision in the case, given by Justice Jaspal Singh, given in favour of the plaintiff, restricted the Indian Government from causing any further loss to the plaintiff by destroying the property. The interim ruling, given in 1992, established two central points about the ambit of moral rights within India. Firstly, that the moral right of integrity under Indian Law can in fact protect an artistic work from outright destruction and secondly, that the Government has a duty of care towards artworks in its possession. This gave rise to amendments in the Copyright Act in 1994. Even though the purported primary motive of the Government was to bring the Indian Act in conformity with the Berne Convention, the wording of the amendment seemed to be a direct reaction to the interim ruling. Under the amended Section 57, a legal claim by an author against unauthorized modifications to his work had to establish that the treatment of the work has been prejudicial to his honour or reputation. The revised Section 57 corresponded to Article 6bis of the Berne Convention and also provided that failure to display a work, or to display it in accordance with the wishes of the author, would not qualify as a violation of the author’s moral rights.
In light of this amendment in 1994, an important question that Justice Nandrajog needed to address was that of which law would be applicable to the final ruling, the pre amendment or post amendment Copyright Act. There were compelling arguments for both the sides, as the old provisions of the Copyright Act would apply because they governed the time when the acts of destruction occurred, and when the case was actually filed before the court. On the other hand, he could have said that the post amended provisions should apply because they reflected the currently policy of the Govt. and were actually in force at the time of the judgment. However, he sidestepped the question and chose neither of the paths, arguing that the law must be read to fulfil the higher objective of protecting our cultural heritage, in light of the many international treaties on cultural heritage that India is a signatory to. The artwork in question constituted an ‘outstanding work of art’ and in such cases there is an overriding obligation to protect their integrity, no matter which law is applied.

Treat such cases as if only the year is known, so use {{birth year and age|YYYY}} or a similar option. --> | birth_place = | death_date = 1504 - 1512 <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = Cretan School | spouse = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = }} '''Andreas Pavias''' (born 1440 - died between 1504 and 1512) was a [[Cretan School]] painter and teacher of painting. He was active in [[Heraklion]], [[Crete]] during the second half of the 15th century.
== Life == He lived and worked in [[Heraklion]], [[Crete]] (referred to at the time by the Venetians as [[Kingdom of Candia|Candia]]) during the second half of the 15th century. In 1470 there was evidence he was teaching painting to children of nobles. He died between 1504 and 1512.
Like other contemporaries [[Cretan School]] painters painted pictures by following different styles and yielding various iconographic themes in the [[Byzantine]] and "italokritika" works. His works addressed Orthodox and [[Catholic]] doctrine. Main means of expression of an image, an object of reverence looked up positions both in churches and monasteries as well as in residential homes.
== Art and work == Considered a teacher, master of art and literature his clientele consisted of wealthy burghers and nobles. The project is small in number but high quality, but the artistic activity was so long it is likely to assume that even latent projects mainly western churches or in private collections. Archival documents in Venice provide information about the life of the painter in Heraklion, Crete, covering the period from 1470, appearing as a teacher of painting, until 1512 when he is recorded as already dead. The years 1471, 1473 and 1479 he was involved in economic affairs in Heraklion, where he lived. On April 23, 1480 signed as a witness: magister Andreas Pavias, penctor. 1481 rented a house (on Georgio Grin) in Vourgo Candia. In 1482 he signed a contract with Angelo Pitzamanos, to teach his son painting for five years. In the years 1482, 1483, 1486 and 1491 in the name refers to acts of purchase and sale and rental in Heraklion, from which it appears that it had considerable fortune. On October 24, 1492 by Andreas Pavias pentor signed a contract with Manousos Koukou, a resident of Heraklion, to teach his son painting for five years. In 1493 he was again involved in economic affairs in Heraklion. During the period of the years 1493-1505 we know that the Catholic Bishop Giovanni Battista Lagni commissioned an image of the Pieta in Crete, which is currently in [[Rossano]].
On 23 May 1499, he agreed to teach painting for three years to Niccolo da Napoli, and on July 16 of the Andreas Pavias depentor same time signed an apprenticeship contract for four years with John Ploraio. On November 19, 1499 he agreed with Jewish Aquilo (Soulouma) to teach her son not only painting but also letters to eight years.
On 7 May 1500, he requested to be returned a picture of the Nativity Angel painter. In March of the same year again referred to economic matters. On July 26, 1500 handwritten signatures into a covenant said: I am the man (let) the Pavias (we) witness without specifying whether it is the painter. 1502 A. Pavias refers to a document relating to a financial matter and July 8, 1503 signed as a witness, magister Andreas Pavias, together with the painter Marco Amaranto. According to a document of 1504, he had purchased warehouse in Heraklion, the same year the painter, resident Vourgo Candia, promises to give his adoptive daughter Agnes considerable dowry: 500 hyperpyra and 10 gold ducats, which include the value of a house in Candia, gold, silver, gems, clothes, bed and jewelry.
On November 8, 1512 the painter has already died, a document refers to his widow Marietta. In 1514 again referred to as administrator of the estate of the painter's widow, which gives an area of the monastery of the Holy Spirit, she belonged and was outside the Vourgo Candia. The same Maria refers to document 1516.a.
== Influence == Andreas Pavias was able to paint in a variety of styles. Created iconographic types -protypa for posterity (Crucifixion -pieta). To fulfill a of the often xaraktirizetai from entoni realistic mood, laid due to an earlier trend, antiklasikou character of Palaiologian painting. In "italokritika" projects follows the Late Gothic style, that realism fits with his artistic temperament.
H installing the student, [[Angelos Pitzamanos]] in Italy is not irrelevant to the trends of the painting of Andreas Pavias his teacher. Adaptation to more modern Italian influences (Bellini), recognized in the art of Nicholas Tzafouri, meticulous miniatures with "lyrical mood," which creates this new iconographic types (Akra Tapeinosi).

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Tapisserie de l'apocalypse.jpg | painting_alignment = Right | image_size = 300px | title = The Apocalypse Tapestry | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Jean Bondol]] and Nicholas Bataille | year = 1377–1382 | type = [[Tapestry]] | city = [[Angers]] | museum = Musée de la Tapisserie, [[Château d'Angers]] | owner = }} The '''Apocalypse Tapestry''' is a large medieval French set of [[tapestries]] commissioned by [[Louis I, Duke of Anjou|Louis I]], the [[Duke of Anjou]], and produced between 1377 and 1382. It depicts the story of the [[Apocalypse]] from the [[Book of Revelation]] by [[Saint John the Divine]] in colourful images, spread over a number of sections that originally totalled 90 scenes. Despite being lost and mistreated in the late 18th century, the tapestry was recovered and restored in the 19th century and is now on display at the [[Chateau d'Angers]]. It is the oldest French medieval tapestry to have survived, and historian Jean Mesqui considers it "one of the great artistic interpretations of the revelation of Saint John, and one of the masterpieces of French cultural heritage".<ref name=MesquiP49>Mesqui, p.49.</ref>
==History== [[File:Angers Apocalypse Loire Valley 2007a.jpg|thumb|Detail of the tapestry (reverse side), showing an important figure seated under a ceremonial shade]] The Apocalypse Tapestry was commissioned by Louis I, the Duke of Anjou in the late 1370s.<ref name=MesquiP44>Mesqui, p.44.</ref> Louis instructed [[Jean Bondol]], a Flemish artist, to draw the sketches that would form the model for the tapestry, which was then woven in Paris between 1377 and 1380 by Nicholas Bataille.<ref>Mesqui, p.44; Klein, p.191.</ref> The tapestry was probably finally complete by 1382.<ref name=MesquiP44/> It was unusual for a tapestry to be commissioned by a buyer to a specific design in this way.<ref>Bell, p.64.</ref> It is uncertain how Louis used the tapestry; it was probably intended to be displayed outside, supported by six wooden structures, possibly arranged so as to position the viewer near to the centre of the display, imitating a [[jousting]] field.<ref name=MesquiP50>Mesqui, p.50.</ref> The tapestry and its theme would have also helped to bolster the status of Louis's [[Valois dynasty]], then involved in the [[Hundred Years' War]] with England.<ref name=MesquiP50/>
The tapestry shows the story of the Apocalypse from the Book of Revelation by Saint John the Divine.<ref>Bausum, p.70.</ref> In the 14th century, the Apocalypse was a popular story, focusing on the heroic aspects of the last confrontation between good and evil and featuring battle scenes between angels and beasts.<ref>Aberth, p.186; Benton, p.199.</ref> Although many of the scenes in the story included destruction and death, the account ended with the triumphant success of good, forming an uplifting story.<ref>Mesqui, p.45.</ref> Various versions of the Apocalypse story, or cycle, were circulating in Europe at the time and Louis chose to use an Anglo-French Gothic style of the cycle, partially derived from a manuscript he borrowed from his brother, [[Charles V of France]], in 1373.<ref name=MesquiP44/> This version of the Apocalypse had first been recorded in [[Metz]] and then later adapted by English artists; Charles' manuscript had been produced in England around 1250.<ref>Klein, pp.188-189, 191; Aberth, p.190.</ref> Louis may also have been influenced by a particularly grand tapestry given to Charles by the magistrates of [[Lille]] in 1367.<ref>Bell, p.88.</ref>
After a century in the ownership of the dukes of Anjou, [[René of Anjou]] bequeathed the tapestry to [[Angers Cathedral]] in 1480 where it remained for many years.<ref name=MesquiP49/> During the [[French Revolution]] the Apocalypse Tapestry was looted and cut up into pieces. The pieces of the tapestry were used for various purposes: as floor mats, to protect local orange trees from frost, to shore up holes in buildings, and to insulate horse stables.<ref>Benton, p.200; Belozerskaya, p.92.</ref> During the Revolution many medieval tapestries were destroyed, both through neglect and through being melted down to recover the gold and silver used in their designs.<ref>Belozerskaya, p.92.</ref> The surviving fragments were rediscovered in 1848 and preserved, being returned to the cathedral in 1870.<ref name=MesquiP39>Mesqui, p.39.</ref>
The cathedral was not ideal for displaying and preserving the tapestry.<ref name=MesquiP40>Mesqui, p.40.</ref> The neighbouring Chateau d'Angers had been used as a French military base for many years, but transferred to civilian use after the [[Second World War]]. In 1954 the tapestry was moved there, to be displayed in a new gallery designed by French architect Bernard Vitry.<ref name=MesquiP39/> Between 1990 and 2000 the castle gallery was itself improved, with additional light and ventilation controls installed to protect the tapestry.<ref name=MesquiP40/>
==Description and style==
The tapestry was made in six sections, each {{convert|78|ft|adj=on}} wide by {{convert|20|ft|adj=on}} high, comprising 90 different scenes.<ref>Bausum, p.70.</ref> Each scene had a red or blue background, alternating between the sections.<ref>Benton, p.199.</ref> They would have taken considerable effort to produce, with between 50 and 84 man-years of effort required by the weaving teams.<ref>Bell, p.66.</ref> Only 71 of the original 90 scenes survive today.<ref>Benton, p.200.</ref> The tapestry is dominated by blue, red and ivory coloured threads, supported by orange and green colours, with gilt and silver woven into the wool and silk.<ref>Bausum, p.70; Mesqui, p.48; Bell, p.66.</ref> These colours are now considerably faded on the front of the tapestry but were originally similar to the deep and vibrant hues seen on the back of the tapestry panels.<ref>Bausum, p.70; Mesqui, p.48.</ref>
Jean Bondol's weaving follows the Franco-Flemish school of tapestry design, with rich, realist, fluid images placed into a simple, clear structure through the course of the tapestry.<ref>Mesqui, p.48.</ref> As a result, the angels and monsters are depicted with considerable energy and colour, the impact reinforced by the sheer size of the tapestry, which allows them to be portrayed slightly larger than life-size.<ref>Benton, p.200; Bausum, p.70.</ref> Various approaches are taken in the tapestry to interpreting the allegorical language used by St John in his original text; in particular, the tapestry takes an unusual approach to portraying the [[Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse|Fourth Horseman]] of the Apocalypse, [[Death (personification)|Death]]. The depiction of Death in this tapestry follows the style then becoming popular in England: he is represented as a decaying corpse, rather than the more common 14th century portrayal of Death as a conventional, living person.<ref>Aberth, pp.187, 190.</ref>

[[File:Norblin - Marchand d'images.jpg|thumb|Dealer of art in [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]], (Drawn by [[Jan Piotr Norblin]])]] An '''art dealer''' is a person or company that buys and sells [[works of art]]. Art dealers' professional associations serve to set high standards for accreditation or membership and to support art exhibitions and shows.<ref name="ADAA">[http://www.artdealers.org/dnloads/adaa_guide.pdf Collector's Guide to Working with Art Dealers, 45th Anniversary Edition, The Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA), New York] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008045449/http://www.artdealers.org/dnloads/adaa_guide.pdf |date=October 8, 2013 }}</ref>
==Role== An art dealer typically seeks out various [[artist]]s to represent, and builds relationships with [[art collector|collectors]] and [[museum]]s whose interests are likely to match the work of the represented artists. Some dealers are able to anticipate [[market trends]], while some prominent dealers may be able to influence the taste of the market. Many dealers specialize in a particular style, period, or region. They often travel internationally, frequenting [[Art exhibition|exhibitions]], [[auctions]], and artists' [[studio]]s looking for good buys, little-known treasures, and exciting new works. When dealers buy works of art, they resell them either in their galleries or directly to collectors. Those who deal in [[contemporary art]] usually exhibit artists' works in their galleries, and take a percentage of the price the works sell for.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=B7u8s0SN7KcC&pg=PA81&dq=art+dealer%27s+percentage+of+the+artwork+price&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AAbXUoOSH-iy0QXf44DQDA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=art%20dealer's%20percentage%20of%20the%20artwork%20price&f=false Alan D. Bryce, ''Art Smart: The Intelligent Guide to Investing in the Canadian Art Market''], Dundurn, 2007. {{ISBN|1550026763}}, 9781550026764</ref>
==Job requirements== [[File:Gillis van Tilborgh - A Picture Gallery.jpg|thumb|300px|''A Picture Gallery'' by [[Gillis van Tilborch]], 1660s]] Art dealers often study the [[history of art]] before entering on their careers. Related careers that often cross-over include [[curator]]s of museums and [[art auction]] firms are industry-related careers.<ref name="ADAA" /> Gallery owners who do not succeed may seek to work for more successful galleries. Others pursue careers as [[art critic]]s, academics, curators of museums or auction houses, or practicing artists.<ref>[http://www.princetonreview.com/careers.aspx?cid=12 Career: Art Dealer, The Princeton Review]</ref>
Dealers have to understand the business side of the art world. They keep up with trends in the market and are knowledgeable about the style of art people want to buy. They figure out how much they should pay for a piece and then estimate the resale price. They are also often passionate and knowledgeable about art. Those who deal with contemporary art promote new artists, creating a market for the artists' works and securing financial success for themselves. The art world is subject to economic booms and bust just like any other market. Art dealers must be economically conscious in order to maintain their livelihoods. The mark ups of art work must be carefully monitored. If prices and profits are too large, then investments may be devalued should an overstock or economic downturn occur.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/04/15/smbusiness/singing_in_rain_art.fsb/index.htm?section=magazines_fsb | author=Cowley, Stacy | title=Amid art boom, dealers brace for a bust | publisher=Fortune Small Business | date=2008-04-16 | accessdate=2008-06-03}}</ref>
To determine an artwork's value, dealers inspect the objects or paintings closely, and compare the fine details with similar pieces. Some dealers with many years of experience learn to identify unsigned works by examining stylistic features such as brush strokes, color, form. They recognize the styles of different periods and individual artists. Often art dealers are able to distinguish authentic works from [[forgeries]] (although even dealers are sometimes fooled).<ref name="ADAA" />
==Notable art dealers== [[File:Frans Francken the Younger - A visit to the Art Dealer - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|300px|''A visit to the Art Dealer'' by [[Frans Francken the Younger]], early 1600s]] * [[Guillam Forchondt|Guillam Forchondt the Elder]] (1608–1678)
A 17th century Flemish Baroque painter and art dealer based in Antwerp. He established an important art dealing business with international connections in Europe maintained by his extended family. He originally trained as a painter and cabinet maker but built a reputation through his international art business. His children became art dealers who settled in various cities in Europe such as Venice, Paris, Vienna, Prague, Linz, [[Passau]] and [[Cadiz]] where they supplied an elite clientele with a variety of art objects. When in the 1670s Flanders suffered a severe economic downturn due mostly to an invasion by the French, Guillam Forchondt and his brother Melchior the Younger became art entrepreneurs by hiring lesser painters to create group projects such as large commissioned copies of famous works or large decorative objects. At one point, the ''Brothers Forchondt'' had 60 painters in service for export to France, Austria, Spain and Portugal.<ref name=RKD>[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/28613 Guilliam Forchondt] in the [[RKD]]</ref>
* [[Matthijs Musson]] ([[Antwerp]], 1598–3 November 1678)
A painter and art dealer based in Antwerp, who helped popularize artists of the 17th century [[Antwerp school]] by marketing them throughout Europe.<ref name="maere">J. de Maere, Jennifer A. Martin, and Marie Wabbes. ''Illustrated Dictionary of 17th Century Flemish Painters''. Brussels: Renaissance du livre, 1994; p. 294. {{ISBN|2-8041-1858-4}}</ref> Many of his correspondences have been published and studies of his business relationships with other dealers across Europe have established ideas about the art trade and its economics.<ref name="maere" /><ref>Neil De Marchi, [[Hans J. Van Miegroet]] and Matthew E. Raiff, "Dealer-Dealer Pricing in the Mid Seventeenth-Century Antwerp to Paris Art Trade," in Michael North and David Ormrod, ''Art Markets in Europe, 1400-1800'', Aldershot: Ashgate, 1998; pp. 113–130. {{ISBN|1-84014-630-3}}</ref> * [[Larry Gagosian]] (born 1945) Head of the multimillion-dollar [[Gagosian Gallery]] group.
* [[Arne Glimcher]] (born 1938) Glimcher is the founder of The [[Pace Gallery]] and is widely known as one of the art world's most powerful dealers. The Pace Gallery represents contemporary artists including [[Chuck Close]], [[Tara Donovan]], [[David Hockney]], [[Maya Lin]] and [[Kiki Smith]]. It also represents the estates of several artists, including [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Agnes Martin]], [[Ad Reinhardt]], and [[Alexander Calder]].<ref name="Bloomberg">[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601088&sid=a1O4sidv4.xg&refer=muse Dealer Arne Glimcher Thinks Art Market Is `A Little Bit Crazy' - Bloomberg.com]</ref> During his career he has worked closely with important artists including [[Jean Dubuffet]], [[Robert Rauschenberg]], [[Louise Nevelson]], and [[Lucas Samaras]]. In 2007, Glimcher received the Distinguished Alumni Award from the Massachusetts College of Art and Design.
* [[Edith Halpert]] (1900–1970) Halpert was born in 1900 in [[Odessa]], arrived in the U.S. as a penniless Russian [[Jewish]] immigrant and grew to become a pioneering New York City art dealer, transforming the landscape of [[Modern art]]. Over her forty-year career from 1926 through the 1960s, Halpert brought recognition and market success to many [[avant-garde]] American artists. Her establishment The Downtown Gallery, one of the first in Greenwich Village, introduced and showcased many modern art luminaries. Halpert died at age 70 a multimillionaire, with [[Sotheby's]] crediting her with having put modernist painting auctions on the map. Its posthumous sale of her collection went for million in 1973.
* [[Klaus Perls]] Perls (1912–2008) was born and raised in Berlin. He studied art history in Munich, but was forced to finish his education in Basel, Switzerland, as the Nazis were no longer allowing degrees for Jews. He ran Perls Galleries for over 60 years. His gallery dealt with contemporary American artists, modern works from the School of [[Paris]] and Mexican and South American art. Perls also developed an interest in art from Benin and built a sizable collection. He was not only an art dealer, but also a donor as he contributed many significant works of art to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. He died June 2, 2008 in [[Mount Kisco, New York|Mount Kisco, N.Y.]] at age 96.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/05/arts/design/05perls.html?ref=design | author=Grimes, William | title=Klaus Perls, Art Dealer Who Gave Picassos to the Met, Dies at 96 | publisher=New York Times | date=2008-06-05 | accessdate=2008-06-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080612003117/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/05/arts/design/05perls.html?ref=design| archivedate= 12 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
* [[Martha Hopkins Struever]] Struever was born in 1931 in [[Milan, Indiana]]. She attended the [[Wood Tobe Coburn School|Tobé-Coburn School For Fashion Careers]] in [[New York City, New York|New York City]], after obtaining her Bachelor of Science degree from [[Purdue University]] in [[Lafayette, Indiana]] in 1953. She began collecting and dealing in [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] art in 1971, and is regarded as a leading scholar on historic and contemporary [[Pueblo Indian]] pottery and [[Pueblo]] and [[Navajo people|Navajo]] Indian jewelry. She has authored books on [[Charles Loloma]], the foremost [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] jeweler, and [[Dextra Quotskuyva]], the pre-eminent contemporary [[Hopi]] potter, as well as exhibition catalogues on [[Hopi]] potter [[Iris Nampeyo]] and other [[Hopi]] art, and has guest curated museum shows in several cities.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.atada.org/ATADA_News2-07.html |author=Bauver, Robert |date=Spring 2007 |title=ATADA Lifetime Achievement Awards - Antique Tribal Arts Community Honors Its Own |journal=ATADA News |publisher=Antique Tribal Arts Dealers Association, Inc. |pages= |accessdate=2009-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718134436/http://atada.org/ATADA_News2-07.html |archivedate=2009-07-18 |df= }}</ref>
* [[Jacques Seligmann]] German-born Seligmann (1858–1923) moved to Paris in 1874 where he set up an antiquarian business in 1880. Benefiting from the interest of clients such as [[Edmond de Rothschild]], he moved to the [[Place Vendôme]] in 1900 and in 1904 opened an office in New York. In 1909, he acquired the [[Polish Embassy, Paris#The H.C3.B4tel de Monaco|Hôtel de Monaco]] in Paris where he was able to impress his more important clients such as the Russian [[Stroganovs|Stroganoff family]] and the high-flying British politician [[Sir Philip Sassoon]]. In New York, he developed interest in European art attracting collectors such as [[Benjamin Altman]], [[William Randolph Hearst]] and [[J. P. Morgan]]. On his death, his son [[Germain Seligman]] continued to run [[Jacques Seligmann & Company]].
* [[John Weber (art dealer)|John Weber]] (1932-2008) Weber was born in 1932 in [[Los Angeles]]. He was a radio corpsman in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] during the [[Korean War]] before receiving a bachelor's degree from [[Antioch College]] in [[Yellow Springs, Ohio]] in 1958. As a contemporary art dealer, Weber was ahead of his time as he was one of the early promotors of Conceptual Art, Post-Minimalist sculpture and Italian Arte Povera. He was the director of several galleries throughout his career and helped organize shows that featured big names such as [[Robert Indiana]], [[Richard Long (artist)|Richard Long]] and [[Andy Warhol]]. Weber died May 23, 2008 in [[Hudson, New York|Hudson, N.Y.]] at age 75.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/01/arts/design/01weber.html?ref=design | author=Smith, Roberta | title=John Weber, 75, Contemporary-Art Dealer, Is Dead | publisher=New York Times | date=2008-06-01 | accessdate=2008-06-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080612003444/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/01/arts/design/01weber.html?ref=design| archivedate= 12 June 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

{{Primary sources|date=January 2010}} The '''Bellagio Declaration''' is a [[Resolution (law)|resolution]] formed in 1993, with the aim of reforming [[intellectual property law]]s in order to foster the protection of [[Folklore|folkloric works]], works of [[cultural heritage]], and the biological and ecological [[know-how]] of traditional peoples.
It was from the 1993 Rockefeller Conference "Cultural Agency/Cultural Authority: Politics and Poetics of Intellectual Property in the Post-Colonial Era".
== External links == * [http://www.cwru.edu/affil/sce/BellagioDec.html Text of Declaration]
[[Category:Intellectual property law]]

The '''Berlin Sculpture-Network''' is a cooperative project between the Antiquities Collection of the [[Berlin State Museums]] and the Institute of [[Classical Archaeology]] at the [[Free University of Berlin]]. It is funded by the [[German Federal Ministry of Education and Research]] within the initiative “Translating Humanities” (“Übersetzungsfunktion von Geisteswissenschaften"). This project aims to reconstruct the spatial, functional and substantive contexts context of ancient sculptures.
The "Berlin Sculpture-Network" project includes a [[database]] of the ancient sculptures in the museums, the associated archival records and current excavation data as well as the collection of all plaster casts in the [[Berlin]] collections. The data will be made available in the online database [[Arachne (archaeological database)|Arachne]].
== Objects ==
Selected research results will be shown in a major exhibition in the [[Pergamon Museum]] in 2011, where an interactive 3D visualization of archaeological monuments of the city of [[Pergamon]] will be introduced to the general public. This virtual [[3D model]] will be a research tool combining the latest research results from the excavations in Pergamon and the reconstruction of the famous city in its surrounding landscape with marble sculptures shown in their original contexts. The exhibition provides a basis for the long-term development of new exhibition concepts for the Berlin [[Antiquities]] collection of the Berlin State Museums.
The "Berlin Sculpture-Network" is a platform for scientific exchange between project members and numerous specialists in and outside of Berlin who research Greek and Roman sculpture and supply scientific contributions to the project.

'''Cadoro''', or '''Cadoro Jewels Corporation''', was a [[Manhattan]]-based jewelry company founded in 1954<ref name=met>{{cite web|title=Cadoro in the collection of the Met.|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/collections/search-the-collections?ft=*&who=Cadoro+Jewels+Corp.|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=26 November 2012}}</ref> by '''Steven Brody''' and '''Daniel Stoenescu''' (aka Staneskieu), specialising in fashionable costume jewelry sold via department stores such as [[Neiman Marcus]] and [[Saks Fifth Avenue]].<ref name=obit>{{cite news|title=Obituary: S. Steven Brody, 75, Designer of Jewelry|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/01/obituaries/s-steven-brody-75-designer-of-jewelry.html|accessdate=26 November 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=1 January 1995}}</ref> The company closed in 1987 following Brody's retirement as president.<ref name=obit/>
==Company history== Steven Stuart Brody (1919<ref name=obit/> or 1926,<ref name=moma>{{cite web |title=Ring Stephen (''sic'') Brody (American, born 1926) and Dan Stoenescu (American, born 1921) |url=http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?object_id=4736 |publisher=MoMA |accessdate=26 November 2012}}</ref> Philadelphia – 23 December 1994) initially studied business administration at [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School, Pennsylvania]],<ref name=lambert>{{cite book|last=Lambert|first=Eleanor|title=World of fashion : people, places, resources|year=1976|publisher=R.R. Bowker Co.|location=New York|isbn=0835206270|pages=213}}</ref> then attended the [[Curtis Institute of Music]]. After a stint as an actor in radio soap operas,<ref name=lambert/> he went to Paris, where he met Daniel Stoenescu (1921<ref name=moma/>-after 1970), son of the Romanian artist [[Eustațiu Stoenescu]], and nephew of [[Liane de Pougy|Princess Ghika]],<ref name=lambert/> who proposed they go into jewelry design together.<ref name=alice>{{cite news|last=Hughes|first=Alice|title=A Woman's New York|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19660824&id=ArIhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BJwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6093,4748557|accessdate=26 November 2012|newspaper=The Reading Eagle|date=24 August 1966}}</ref>
Cadoro, which was launched on [[Fifth Avenue]], became known for inventive jewelry which used [[Chenille stem|chenille]] and plastics alongside more traditional crystals, brushed gold, and enamel for designs which were bought by the likes of [[Wallis Simpson|the Duchess of Windsor]] and [[Barbra Streisand]].<ref name=alice/> In 1969, Cadoro also designed body jewellery in the form of filigree bras and breastplates for wearing with trendy [[see-through clothing]] to enable followers of fashion to preserve their modesty.<ref name=nemy>{{cite news|last=Nemy|first=Enid|title=No Matter What You Call It, Body Jewelry Is Made to Top Nudity |url=http://fultonhistory.com/newspaper%202/Utica%20NY%20Daily%20Observer/Utica%20NY%20Observer%201969%20pdf/Utica%20NY%20Observer%201969%20-%201451.PDF|accessdate=26 November 2012 |newspaper=Utica Observer Dispatch|date=17 February 1969}}</ref> Cadoro's metal "breastplates" were inspired by a statue of [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] found at [[Pompeii]].<ref name=nemy/> The following year in 1970 Brody and Stoenescu were two of a group of costume jewelry designers awarded special [[Coty Awards]], alongside [[Alexis Kirk]], [[Marty Ruza]], [[Clifton Nicholson|Cliff Nicholson]] and the first black recipient of a Coty, [[Bill Smith (jewelry designer)|Bill Smith]].<ref name=mcdowell>{{cite book|last=McDowell|first =Colin |title=McDowell's Directory of Twentieth Century Fashion|publisher=Frederick Muller|year=1984|pages=299–301|isbn =0-584-11070-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Banik|first=Sheila|title=Bill Smith: The Maverick|journal=Black Enterprise |date=July 1981 |pages=36 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rqJ_ZvaSPggC&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Cadoro designs for that year were Indian-themed, following on from an African and [[Pre-Columbian art]]-inspired collection in polished wood and carved gold and silver.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lambert|first=Eleanor|title=Ethnic Theme Monopolises Front Seat in Fashion|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2506&dat=19700919&id=45lIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vgkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4164,4626742|accessdate=29 November 2012|newspaper=The News and Courier|date=19 September 1970}}</ref>
Examples of Cadoro jewelry are held by the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] and the [[Museum of Modern Art]].<ref name=met/><ref name=moma/>
Brody became president of the company in 1960, and when he retired in 1987, the company also closed down. He died at the [[Beth Israel Medical Center]] on December 23, 1994, of pneumonia following a long illness.<ref name=obit/>

{{Short description|American artist}} '''Carol Es''' (born {{Birth date|1968|7|20|mf=yes}}) is a self-taught visual artist, writer, musician (drummer), and [[book artist]] who lives and works in [[Los Angeles, California]]. She has written articles for [[Coagula Art Journal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esart.com/news/press/coagula-botello.pdf|title=Rochelle Botello, Down by the River on Tenterhooks|publisher=Coagula Art Journal, Issue #91, March 2008|accessdate=2015-07-17}}</ref> and the [[Huffington Post]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/carol-es/a-snow-white-story-on-its-head_b_3263641.html|title=A Snow White Story Turned on Its Head|publisher=Huffington Post Arts Section|accessdate=2013-07-12}}</ref> As a musician, she has played for 20 years as an R&B drummer touring and recording drums with various artists. She played drums on Rickie Lee Jones' [[Ghostyhead]] album in 1997.
Her Artists' books are featured in the [[J. Paul Getty Trust]] Research Institute Library in Los Angeles,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esart.com/news/press/dailybreeze-caroles.pdf|title=A Pattern of Creativity by Josh Grossberg|publisher=Daily Breeze, 5 March 2006|accessdate=2015-07-17}}</ref> [[National Museum of Women in the Arts]], [[Brooklyn Museum]], [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in Paris, and also in prominent university collections such as the Arthur and Mata Jaffe Collection at [[Florida Atlantic University Library]], UC Irvine, [[Otis College of Art & Design]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.otis.edu/press-release/binding-desire-unfolding-artists-books|title=Binding Desire: UNFOLDING ARTISTS BOOKS|publisher=AN EXHIBITION AT BEN MALTZ GALLERY from the Millard Sheets Library Special Collections, 2014.|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> and the [[UCLA Library]] Special Collections.
Es' mixed media paintings have exhibited at the [[Riverside Art Museum]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redlandsdailyfacts.com/general-news/20070206/yellow-brick-muse-leads-to-riverside|title=Yellow Brick Muse Leads to Riverside by Penny E, Schwartz|publisher=Redlands Daily Facts|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> Torrance Art Museum in Torrance, California, and the [[Craft and Folk Art Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.semel.ucla.edu/tarjan/news/15/feb/09/carol-es-nadc-featured-artist-month|title=Carol Es is the NADC Featured Artist of the Month|publisher=Tarjan Center at UCLA/National Arts and Disability Center|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref>
Es is the recipient of a [[Pollock-Krasner Foundation]] Fellowship Award,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esart.com/news/press/fiberarts-carol-es.pdf|title=News & Notes, AWARDS|publisher=Fiber Arts Magazine, Nov/Dec Issue, 2009|accessdate=2015-07-17}}</ref> two Durfee Foundation ARC Grants, and was awarded the 2014 [[Wynn Newhouse Award]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.syr.edu/ninth-annual-wynn-newhouse-awards-exhibition-opens-april-14-at-palitz-gallery-42147/|title=Ninth Annual Wynn Newhouse Awards by Scott McDowell|publisher=Syracuse University News|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref>
As a visual artist, Es is known for creating personal narratives. She has used past experience as the fuel for her subject matter, transforming a broken history into a positive and spiritual resolve. Candid experiences are laid bare and forged directly into her paintings, drawings, soft sculptures, mixed media installations, and handmade books.[http://esart.com/] In 2015, Los Angeles Art Critic, [[Peter Frank (art critic)|Peter Frank]] wrote: "An autodidact, Es has long embodied her interests and her struggles - in painted and drawn and even sculpted and sewn imagery - darkly whimsical forms and figures whose deft fluidity have the eye "going for a walk with a line" (in the words of [[Paul Klee]], who strongly influenced Es) but aggressively trouble the mind."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artillerymag.com/carol-es/|title=Carol Es - Shulamit Gallery / Los Angeles|work=Artillery|date=July 2015|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>
In 2010, Los Angeles art critic, A. Moret wrote: "The viewer activates the past as Es rewrites the story by mending a broken history and constructing a new narrative. Carol Es has transformed the past that once plagued her existence into her raison d’ être.<ref>{{cite web|last=Moret|first=A|url=http://whitehotmagazine.com/articles/carol-es-george-billis-gallery/2151|title=Carol Es @ George Billis Gallery|work=Whittehot magazine|date=November 2010|accessdate=17 July 2015}}</ref>
Es' artwork has been reviewed in ''[[LA Weekly]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/the-best-free-la-art-parties-this-week-5438047|title=Best Free LA Art Parties by Shana Nya Dambrot|publisher=LA Weekly|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> Artillery Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artillerymag.com/carol-es/|title=Carol Es, Shulamit Gallery Los Angeles by Peter Frank|publisher=Artillery Magazine|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> Art LTD,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esart.com/news/press/ces_artltd2015.pdf|title=Carol Es, Exodus by Simone Kussatz|publisher=Art LTD Magazine|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> ArtScene Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visualartsource.com/index.php?page=editorial&pcID=36&aID=2751|title=Carol Es, Shulamit Gallery by Moly Enholm|publisher=ArtScene Magazine|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> Whitehot Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whitehotmagazine.com/articles/carol-es-exodus/3172|title=Carol Es, Exodus by Megan Abrahams|publisher=Whitehot Magazine, Los Angeles, CA|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> Jewish Journal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/picks_clicks/article/calendar_picks_and_clicks_feb._16_22_2013|title=Picks & Clicks: "INTERSECTING PATHS: ART AND HEALING" by Ryan Torok|publisher=The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> and the Huffington Post.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mat-gleason/summer-in-the-studio-la-a_b_914605.html#s319381title=Chinatown_is_not|title=Summer in the Studio: LA Artists Create in Paradise by Mat Gleason|publisher=Huffington Post Arts Section|accessdate=2015-07-15}}</ref> She has been represented by [[Shulamit Gallery]] in Venice California and George Billis Gallery Los Angeles. She is currently working on an autobiography.

{{Infobox building | name = Castle of Verzuolo | native_name = Castello di Verzuolo | image = Verzuolo-IMG 1179.JPG | image_size = <!-- omitted to display at user's default size --> | alt = | caption = View of the Castle of Verzuolo | former_names = | alternate_names = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = Location within Piedmont | building_type = | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | location = [[Verzuolo]], [[Piedmont]] | client = | owner = [[Italian government]] | current_tenants = | landlord = | location_country = Italy | coordinates = {{coord|44.6036|7.4696|type:landmark_region:IT|display=inline,title}} | altitude = | start_date = | completion_date = | inauguration_date = 1377 | demolition_date = | height = | diameter = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | architect = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = | awards = | parking = | website = | references = }}
The '''Castle of Verzuolo''' ({{lang-it|Castello di Verzuolo}}) is a medieval [[castle]] in the [[Piedmont]] region of Italy, near [[Verzuolo]], [[Province of Cuneo]].<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Historiae patriae Monumenta:|publisher=Carlo Baudi di Vesme|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=xs5QAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA2087|accessdate= }}</ref> It is located around {{convert|6|km|mi}} from the city of [[Saluzzo]] and {{convert|84|km|mi}} from [[Turin]].<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=A General Gazetteer ... Illustrated with maps|publisher=Richard BROOKES (M.D.)|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=neBhAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA721|accessdate= }}</ref>
== History == The castle was originally built in the 11th century and was modified in its original structure by order of [[Frederick II, Marquess of Saluzzo|Frederick II]] in 1377.<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Dizionario geografico-storico-statistico-commerciale degli stati del Redi ..|publisher=Goffredo Casalis|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=EQhTAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA56|accessdate= }}</ref> The successors of Frederick II continued modifying the structure of the building, turning it into the main fortress of the [[Marquisate of Saluzzo]].<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Storia di Saluzzo dal XVe al XIXe secolo, Volume 1|publisher=Carlo Fedele Savio|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=o_M-AQAAMAAJ|accessdate= }}</ref>
In 1528, [[Giovanni Ludovico, Marquess of Saluzzo]], was imprisoned in the castle.<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Dizionario di erudizione storico|publisher=Italy|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=qKOu__OaucYC&pg=PA308|accessdate= }}</ref>
In 1600 the castle facade was renovated, changing its aspect from that of a military fortress to that of a luxury mansion, and it has since been used as a summer residence of illustrious personalities, including [[Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy]], and [[Giambattista Bodoni]].<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=Il Castello|publisher=Comune di Verzuolo|publication-place= |page= |url=http://www.comune.verzuolo.cn.it/archivio/pagine/Il_Borgo_medievale.asp|accessdate= }}</ref>
On 18 June 1916, valuable documents referring to the history of Piedmont were lost in the collapse of one of the castle's two towers.<ref>{{Citation |last= |first= |year= |title=I giornali dei viaggi|publisher=Giorgio Gallesio, Enrico Baldini|publication-place= |page= |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=A58fAQAAIAAJ|accessdate= }}</ref>

{{Use Canadian English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Celine: Through the Eyes of the World | image = TTEOTW.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | film name = | director = Stéphane Laporte | producer = [[Julie Snyder]] | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | starring = [[Celine Dion]]
[[René Angélil]]
René-Charles Angélil | narrator = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | distributor = [[Sony Pictures Entertainment|The Hot Ticket]] | released = {{Film date|2010|02|16|df=yes|[[Miami]]}} | runtime = 180 minutes | country = Canada | language = {{flat list| *English *French }} | budget = | gross = }} '''''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World''''' is a [[Documentary film|documentary]]–[[concert film]] chronicling the life of Canadian singer, [[Celine Dion]] during her 2008–2009 [[Taking Chances World Tour]]. It premiered in [[Miami]] on 16 February 2010 and was released by The Hot Ticket in theaters in North America on 17 February 2010. It was also released in Australia and the United Kingdom. The film received mixed reviews from critics, with most of them indicating it is mainly for the fans. ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' grossed $1,027,341 in Canada alone and became the number-one domestic movie there. It was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on 29 April 2010 in Australia and in early May 2010 in Europe and North America. The home version of ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' includes an additional hour of footage not seen in the film's limited theatrical run in February 2010. In Francophone countries, it was entitled '''''Céline: autour du monde'''''. The DVD/Blu-ray release was commercially successful reaching number one on the charts in Canada, United Kingdom and Belgium, and number two in the United States, France, Australia, New Zealand, Netherlands, Sweden, Argentina and South Africa. It also peaked inside top ten in many other countries around the world. ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' was certified [[Music Canada#Certification-awards|two-times Diamond]] in Canada, [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique#Certification-awards|Platinum]] in France, and [[RIAA certification#Video Longform|Gold]] in the United States and Australia. {{no plot|date=November 2015}} ==Background and release== During the [[Taking Chances World Tour]], Dion played concerts in five continents, 25 countries and 93 cities, selling more than three million tickets.{{cite web|title=Celine: Through the Eyes of the World, an expanded DVD edition of the acclaimed documentary & Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert, a new live DVD/CD, available in May|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/press/celine-through-eyes-world-expanded-dvd-edition-acclaimed-documentary-taking-chances-world-tour|date=6 April 2010|accessdate=6 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814064625/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/press/celine-through-eyes-world-expanded-dvd-edition-acclaimed-documentary-taking-chances-world-tour|archivedate=14 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} Running from February 2008 through February 2009, featuring both Anglophone and Francophone setlists, the tour broke attendance and box office records at venues around the world. In December 2009, [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] announced that their division, The Hot Ticket will bring a special motion picture entitled ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' to theaters.{{cite web|title=Celine Dion Entertains the World in The Hot Ticket's Presentation of 'Celine: Through the Eyes of the World' |publisher=[[PR Newswire]]|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/celine-dion-entertains-the-world-in-the-hot-tickets-presentation-of-celine-through-the-eyes-of-the-world-78432527.html|date=3 December 2009|accessdate=3 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://fr.canoe.ca/divertissement/cinema/nouvelles/2010/02/05/12759166-jdm.html|title=Céline à l'état pur|author=Michelle Coudé-Lord|publisher=[[Canoe.ca]]|date=5 February 2010|accessdate=5 February 2010}} Intercutting concert performances of Dion's biggest hits with behind-the-scenes footage, the documentary depicts the singer's life during the Taking Chances World Tour, giving fans the unique opportunity to follow Dion everywhere, on stage, backstage, and enjoying free time with her family. It was filmed by Jean Lamoureux and directed by Stéphane Laporte. According to Dion herself, "This was an amazing world tour, but there's a lot more than just concert footage on this film. I let the cameras follow me everywhere. There are a lot of ups and downs, and it's very personal... and it's definitely the most intimate journey that I've ever shared with my fans." Dion promoted ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' on 10 February 2010 and ''[[Larry King Live]]'' on 15 February 2010.{{cite web|title=Celine on The Oprah Show Tomorrow!|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95460|date=9 February 2010|accessdate=9 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140625203046/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95460|archivedate=25 June 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Celine on Larry King Live|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95719|date=14 February 2010|accessdate=14 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129211658/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95719|archivedate=29 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} She also attended the [[Miami]] premiere of the movie on 16 February 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.canoe.com/divertissement/cinema/nouvelles/2010/02/11/12847196-jdm.html|title=Dans l'intimité de la diva|author=Michelle Coudé-Lord|publisher=Canoe.ca|date=11 February 2010|accessdate=11 February 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607093717/http://www.canoe.com/divertissement/cinema/nouvelles/2010/02/11/12847196-jdm.html#|archive-date=7 June 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Premiere of "Celine: Through The Eyes of the World" - Regal South Beach Cinema|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/gallery/premiere-celine-through-eyes-world-regal-south-beach-cinema|date=16 February 2010|accessdate=16 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129211658/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/gallery/premiere-celine-through-eyes-world-regal-south-beach-cinema|archivedate=29 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} Starting on 17 February 2010 and for eight days only, fans could enjoy a very limited engagement featured in movie theatres across North America.{{cite web|title='Celine : Through the Eyes of the World' – New Release Details!|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/94939|date=8 January 2010|accessdate=8 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129211658/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/94939|archivedate=29 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} In addition, Sony Pictures Entertainment released ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' in movie theatres in Australia for one week only (18–24 February 2010).{{cite web|title=Celine: Through The Eyes of the World – Australian Release Details|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95339|date=27 January 2010|accessdate=27 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129211658/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95339|archivedate=29 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} The film was also shown in [[Vue Cinemas|Vue]], [[Odeon Cinemas|Odeon]] and [[Cineworld]] cinemas across the United Kingdom in late February 2010.{{cite web|title=Celine: Through the Eyes of the World – UK Release Details|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95984|date=20 February 2010|accessdate=20 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129211658/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/node/95984|archivedate=29 January 2016|df=dmy-all}} ==Concert footage== The following concert performances were included in the documentary. While some showed a full performance, most of the songs were edited and cut short. #"[[I Drove All Night#Celine Dion version|I Drove All Night]]" #"[[Love Can Move Mountains]]" #"[[I've Got the Music in Me]]" #"[[I'm Alive (Celine Dion song)|I'm Alive]]" #"[[We Will Rock You]]" #"Watashi Wa Totemo Shiawase Ne" #"[[A World to Believe In]]" (duet with [[Yuna Ito]]) #"[[To Love You More]]" #"[[Taking Chances (song)#Céline Dion version|Taking Chances]]" #"[[It's All Coming Back to Me Now#Céline Dion|It's All Coming Back to Me Now]]" #"[[Eyes on Me (Celine Dion song)|Eyes on Me]]" #"[[The Show Must Go On (Queen song)|The Show Must Go On]]" #[[The Power of Love (Jennifer Rush song)#Céline Dion version|The Power of Love]]" #"[[Taking Chances|Shadow of Love]]" #"[[All by Myself#Céline Dion version|All by Myself]]" #"[[Alone (Heart song)#Céline Dion version|Alone]]" #"[[Dans un autre monde]]" #"[[Un garçon pas comme les autres (Ziggy)]]" #"[[Pour que tu m'aimes encore]]" #"[[J'irai où tu iras]]" (duet with Marc Langis) #"[[Taking Chances|A Song For You]]" #"[[The Prayer (Celine Dion and Andrea Bocelli song)|The Prayer]]" (duet with [[Andrea Bocelli]] via pre-recorded video) #"[[I'm Your Angel]]" (duet with Barnev Valsaint) #"[[S'il suffisait d'aimer (song)|S'il suffisait d'aimer]]" #"[[My Love (Celine Dion song)|My Love]]" #"[[Because You Loved Me]]" (duet with [[Charice Pempengco|Charice]]) #[[Soul music|Soul]] medley including "[[It's a Man's Man's Man's World]]" #"[[River Deep – Mountain High]]" #"[[My Heart Will Go On]]" ==Critical reception== {{Album ratings |MC = 52/100 |rev1 = [[AllMovie]] |rev1score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/celine-through-the-eyes-of-the-world-v507239|title=Celine: Through the Eyes of the World (2010)|publisher=[[AllMovie]]|accessdate=30 May 2013}} |rev2 = ''[[Boston Herald]]'' |rev2score = A- |rev3 = ''[[Boxoffice (magazine)|Boxoffice]]'' |rev3score = {{Rating|3|5}} |rev4 = ''[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]'' |rev4score = {{Rating|3|5}} |rev5 = ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' |rev5score = {{Rating|2|4}} |rev6 = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |rev6score = {{Rating|2|4}} |rev7 = ''[[Quad-City Times]]'' |rev7score = {{Rating|3|4}} |rev8 = ''[[Toronto Star]]'' |rev8score = {{Rating|3.5|4}} |rev9 = ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' |rev9score = {{Rating|3.5|5}} |rev10 = ''[[USA Today]]'' |rev10score = {{Rating|3|4}} }} Review aggregation website [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[weighted mean]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, gave the film an average score of 52 based on 4 reviews, which indicates "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/celine-through-the-eyes-of-the-world|title=Celine: Through the Eyes of the World|publisher=[[Metacritic]]. [[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=30 May 2013}} Elysa Gardner of ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the movie 3 stars out of 4. She stated that "Celine Dion may be responsible for some of the smoothest, most syrupy pop recordings in recent decades, but in concert, she is a pit bull." {{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/reviews/2010-02-18-celineworld18_ST_N.htm|title=Celine Dion is a dynamo in 'Eyes of World' docu-musical|date=17 February 2010|author=Elysa Gardner|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=17 February 2010}} Lauren Carter from ''[[Boston Herald]]'' gave the film A-. According to her "the film succeeds because it lets us in on Celine the person as much as Celine the performer."{{cite web|url=http://news.bostonherald.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/view/20100219dion_reveals_her_world_offstage/srvc=home&position=also|title=Dion reveals her 'World' offstage|date=19 February 2010|author=Lauren Carter|work=[[Boston Herald]]|accessdate=19 February 2010}} Richard Ouzounian of ''[[Toronto Star]]'' gave the film 3.5 out of 4 stars and said that "it's more than just a collection of the Quebec singer's greatest hits performed in concert, although there's enough high-energy, nicely shot musical numbers to gladden the heart of any Dionista." Also "what makes this a real surprise and something that should strike a chord with those who aren't necessarily Dion fans, is that it also takes you inside: inside the universe of a superstar tour as it careens around the world, as well as inside the mind, heart and – in one unforgettable scene – even the larynx of Dion." In the end, "if you like Dion, the singer, then you will love ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World''. But even if you don't, you can't help but be impressed by this fascinating portrait of a superstar trying very hard to keep her feet on earth while her career keeps soaring ever upward."{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/article/766616--celine-through-the-eyes-of-the-world-gets-deep-with-the-diva|title=Céline: Through The Eyes Of The World gets deep with the diva|date=18 February 2010|author=Richard Ouzounian|work=[[Toronto Star]]|accessdate=18 February 2010}} Michelle Coude-Lord from ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' gave it 3.5 out of 5 stars and wrote that "the movie is a must-see." It "shows Celine as being human, and perfectly depicts the bond between her and [[René Angélil|Angélil]]. It connects the public with Dion's words, successes, career heights and her superstardom." She also noted that "Dion's goal was for her world to remain human, real and authentic. Mission accomplished."{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/entertainment/movies/2010/02/17/12916581.html|title=Celine Dion film a must-see |date=17 February 2010|author=Michelle Coude-Lord |work=[[Toronto Sun]]|accessdate=17 February 2010}} John Griffin of ''[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]'' said that "fans die and go to pop heaven with Stéphane Laporte's sympathetic and even candid documentary about our very own superstar's world tour in 2008-09. Non-fans discover her real appeal in ''Céline: Through the Eyes of the World''." He gave the film 3 out of 5 stars.{{cite web|url=https://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/movie-guide/Review+C%C3%A9line+Through+Eyes+World/2582392/story.html|title=Review: Céline: Through the Eyes of the World|date=18 February 2010|author=John Griffin|work=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]|accessdate=18 February 2010}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Linda Cook of ''[[Quad-City Times]]'' gave the film 3 out of 4 stars and said that she "was pleasantly surprised when she realized the movie had her hooked about 15 minutes into the film". She also said that "it's mesmerizing to see audiences all over the world singing along in French and/or English, and to see the moment when she was presented with the [[Legion of Honour]]." She "enjoyed watching as Celine and her family became tourists in the countries she visited, whether she was taking in the sounds and sights of Africa or Australia. Above all, it's fascinating to watch her music unite the world as audiences from [[Dubai]] and [[Amsterdam]] sing familiar lyrics."{{cite web|url=http://www.qctimes.com/entertainment/columnists/linda-cook/article_640e1c98-1fe7-11df-b240-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Celine' shows a humble, kind superstar|date=22 February 2010|author=Linda Cook|work=[[Quad-City Times]]|accessdate=22 February 2010}} Sara Schieron from ''[[Boxoffice (magazine)|Boxoffice]]'' stated that "in sum, what you see is a woman and a family that handle celebrity with a unique grace." She also said that the "box office will, no doubt, confirm demand for the movie" and gave it 3 stars out of 5.{{cite web|url=http://boxoffice.com/reviews/2010/02/celine-dion-through-the-eyes-o.php|title=Céline Dion: Through the Eyes of the World|date=22 February 2010|author=Sara Schieron|work=[[Boxoffice (magazine)|Boxoffice]]|accessdate=22 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225032923/http://boxoffice.com/reviews/2010/02/celine-dion-through-the-eyes-o.php|archivedate=25 February 2010|df=dmy-all}} According to ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' "you have to admit Dion is the [[James Brown]] of her generation - the hardest working woman in showbusiness".{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/celine-through-the-eyes-of-the-world/article4306747/|title=She's nicer and funnier than you might think|date=19 February 2010|author=Carl Wilson|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=19 February 2010}} ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that "rather than capturing a restless star pushing at her own boundaries, ''Through the Eyes of the World'' finds Dion sitting pretty, on top of the world and happy to stay there".{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/feb/19/entertainment/la-et-celine19-2010feb19|title=Review: 'Céline: Through the Eyes of the World'|date=19 February 2010|author=Sam Adams|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=19 February 2010}} ==Box office== In Canada, after just two days ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' was shown in 81 theatres and entered the domestic chart at number two, earning $240,942. The next week it became number-one domestic movie. It was shown in 89 theatres and earned $476,412. In the third week, it stayed at number one, grossing $309,987 and was shown in 54 theatres. After just three weeks and eight days of screening (17, 18, 20, 21, 22, 25, 27 and 28 February 2010), the movie grossed $1,027,341 in Canada.{{cite web |url=http://7jours.canoe.ca/cinema/nouvelles/2010/03/01/13069841-7j.html |title=Avatar reprend la première place |date=1 March 2010 |author=Isabelle Hontebeyrie |work=7 Jours |accessdate=1 March 2010}} In Australia, ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' earned $213,583 from only 45 screens, with $4,746 per-theater average and became the seventeenth most popular film between 18 and 24 February 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.urbancinefile.com.au/home/boxoffice.asp |title=Most Popular Films For Period Week, February 18–24, 2010 |work=urbancinefile.com.au |accessdate=25 February the World'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on 29 April 2010 in Australia and in early May 2010 in Europe and North America.{{cite web|title=Celine Dion: Through The Eyes Of The World|publisher=celinedion.com|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/music/through-eyes-world|date=4 May 2010|accessdate=4 May countries, it was entitled ''Céline: autour du monde''. Clocking in at three hours, the home version of ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' includes an additional hour of footage not seen in the film's limited theatrical run in February 2010. This film came alongside the DVD/CD release of ''[[Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert]]'' (''Tournée mondiale Taking Chances: le spectacle'' in Francophone countries), which was issued on the same date. A special limited edition deluxe two-DVD set featuring both ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' and ''Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert'' and a 52-page booklet and fold-out souvenir postcards was also released in mid-May 2010. [[QVC]] was also offering ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' with a bonus CD, containing tracks which weren't included on the ''Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert'' CD: "[[I'm Alive (Celine Dion song)|I'm Alive]]," "[[Taking Chances|Fade Away]]," "[[Pour que tu m'aimes encore]]," "[[We Will Rock You]]" and "[[The Show Must Go On (Queen song)|The Show Must Go On]]."{{cite web|title=Celine Dion "Through The Eyes Of The World" DVD w/Bonus CD|publisher=[[QVC|QVC, Inc]]|url=http://www.qvc.com/Celine-Dion-Through-The-Eyes-Of-The-World-DVDwBonus-CD.product.F08860.html|date=11 May 2010|accessdate=11 May 2010}} ===Commercial performance=== In Canada, Dion's new DVD releases debuted at the top three on the [[Nielsen SoundScan]]'s Music Video Chart.{{cite web|title=Tour DVDs Take the Top 3 Spots! |publisher=celinedion.com |url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/tour-dvds-take-top-3-spots |date=13 May 2010 |accessdate=13 May 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819085340/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/tour-dvds-take-top-3-spots |archivedate=19 August 2014 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Celine Dion Receives Three Video Awards For Quick Sales|work=[[Rockstar Weekly]]|url=http://www.rockstarweekly.com/celine-dion-receives-three-video-awards-for-quick-sales.html|date=15 July 2010|accessdate=15 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100718112736/http://www.rockstarweekly.com/celine-dion-receives-three-video-awards-for-quick-sales.html|archivedate=18 July 2010|df=dmy-all}} ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' entered at number one, selling 69,000 copies. Sales of this DVD achieved the second highest one week total for a music DVD, behind Dion's own, ''[[Live in Las Vegas: A New Day...]]'' (2007). ''[[Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert|Tournée mondiale Taking Chances: le spectacle]]'' entered the chart at number two with 31,000 units sold, followed by ''[[Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert]]'' at number three with sales of 8,000 copies. This was only the second time since 2004, after [[Hilary Duff]], that an artist has held the top three positions on the Canadian Music Video Chart. With over 100,000 copies of all three DVDs sold in one week, Dion set an all-time record for music DVD sales in Canada.{{cite web|title=Records de vente pour Céline autour du monde|publisher=[[Canoe.ca]]|url=http://fr.canoe.ca/divertissement/dvd/nouvelles/2010/05/26/14090986-jdm.html|date=26 May 2010|accessdate=26 May 2010}} On 21 May 2010, [[Music Canada|CRIA]] certified all three releases: ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' with [[Music Canada#Certification-awards|two-times Diamond]] award for selling 200,000 copies, ''Tournée mondiale Taking Chances: le spectacle'' with [[Music Canada#Certification-awards|Diamond]] for sales of 100,000 units and ''Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert'' with [[Music Canada#Certification-awards|four-times Platinum]] for selling 40,000 copies.{{cite web|title=Gold Platinum Database: Through the Eyes of World / Autour du monde|publisher=[[Music Canada]]|url=http://www.musiccanada.com/GPSearchResult.aspx?st=Through+the+Eyes+of+World&sa=Celine+Dion&smt=0|date=21 May 2010|accessdate=30 June 2010}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|title=Gold Platinum Database: La tournée mondiale Taking Chances: le spectacle|publisher=Music Canada|url=http://www.musiccanada.com/GPSearchResult.aspx?st=La+tourn%3Fe+mondiale+Taking+Chances%3A+le+spectacle&sa=Celine+Dion&smt=0|date=21 May 2010|accessdate=30 June 2010}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|title=Gold Platinum Database: Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert|publisher=Music Canada|url=http://www.musiccanada.com/GPSearchResult.aspx?st=Taking+Chances+World+Tour%3A+The+Concert&sa=Celine+Dion&smt=0|date=21 May 2010|accessdate=30 June 2010}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This made ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'', one of the fastest selling double-Diamond certification by a Canadian artist. In the United States, Dion entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'}}s Top Music Video Sales chart at numbers one and two with ''Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert'' and ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'', respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/958175/chart-beat-thursday-fox-tvs-lee-glee|title=Chart Beat Thursday: Fox-TV's Lee & "Glee"|date=20 May 2010|accessdate=20 May 2010|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc}} She became the first artist other than [[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)|Bill]] and [[Gloria Gaither]] and the [[Gaither Vocal Band]] to manage a double-debut in the chart's two top spots. ''Taking Chances World Tour: The Concert'' has sold 26,000 copies in the first week and ''Celine: Through the Eyes of the World'' has sold 15,000 units.{{cite web|last=Grein|first=Paul|title=Week Ending May 16, 2010: Battle Of The Home-State Anthems|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/53615/week-ending-may-16-2010-battle-of-the-home-state-anthems/|date=18 May 2010|accessdate=18 May 2010}} On 16 July 2010, [[Recording Industry '''Eleanor Beardsley''' is a correspondent based in [[Paris]] covering French society, politics, economics, culture and gastronomy for [[National Public Radio]]. She has been reporting for NPR from France since 2004.<ref name=NPRstaffbio>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/people/17796129/eleanor-beardsley|title=Eleanor Beardsley|date=2 January 2008|work=NPR.org|accessdate=18 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=Hamilton>{{cite book|last1=Hamilton|first1=John Maxwell|title=Foreign Correspondence|date=2013|publisher=ledge|isbn=1135738769|page=49}}</ref><ref name=VOA>{{cite news|title=American Economic Woes Affect European Tourism|url=http://m.voanews.com/a/a-13-2008-04-02-voa13-66746702/562388.html|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=27 October 2009}}</ref>
==Early life==
Beardsley was raised in [[Columbia, South Carolina]] where her father was a history professor at the [[University of South Carolina]].<ref name=Furman>{{cite news|title=Eleanor Beardsley (Interview)|url=http://www.furman.edu/sites/fumag/Documents/FM09%20Spring%20spreads.pdf|publisher=Furman (alumni magazine)|date=Spring 2009}}</ref> She learned French from reading the [[Asterix]] comic books in French.<ref name=Furman/> Commentators including [[Rod Dreher]] have remarked on how unusual it is to hear a southern accent like Beardsley's coming from a national broadcaster.<ref name=Dreher>{{cite news|last1=[[Rod Dreher]]|title="Does NPR Sound Too White?"|url=http://www.theamericanconservative.com/dreher/does-npr-sound-too-white/|accessdate=16 November 2015|publisher=[[The American Conservative]]|date=31 January 2015}}</ref> [[Ben Yagoda]] describes her pronunciation of, "lawl" (for law), as, "redolent of her native South Carolina."<ref name=Yagoda>{{cite news|last1=Yagoda|first1=Ben|title=That NPR Sound|url=http://chronicle.com/blogs/linguafranca/2014/03/12/that-npr-sound/|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=[[Chronicle of Higher Education]]|date=12 March 2014}}</ref>
She has a B.A. in French from [[Furman University]].<ref name=NPRstaffbio/>
==Career== Beardsley worked on Senator [[Strom Thurmond]]'s staff early in her career.<ref name=ReportersontheJob/> In 2003 she was a spokesman for the [[United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo]].<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=Mufti denies connection between Kosovo Islamic Community, Wahhabis|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=4 January 2003}}</ref><ref name=Sutton>{{cite journal |last=Sutton |first=Andrew |date=Nov 9, 2002 |title=The Black Hole of Europe |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-251572431.html |journal=[[The Spectator]] |accessdate=16 November 2015 |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |subscription=yes}}</ref> Beardsley reported from Kosovo during the [[Kosovo War]].<ref name=ReportersontheJob>{{cite news |date=27 Feb 2002 |title=Reporters on the Job |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2002/0227/p06s02-wogn.html |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref> She has covered the [[Arab Spring]] in Tunisia and presidential elections in France.<ref name=NPRstaffbio/> She also covered the [[November 2015 Paris attacks|terrorist attacks in Paris]] in November 2015.<ref name=NPRstaffbio/>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wes7KK04nQE Lecture at Florida State University] * [http://gadling.com/2008/02/28/talking-travel-and-france-with-npr-journalist-eleanor-beardsley/ Q&A: Talking Travel and France with NPR Journalist Eleanor Beardsley] * [https://soundcloud.com/wdav/biscuit-chat-with-eleanor Biscuit Chat with Eleanor Beardsley]
